articles.headline: A Primer for Young People Starting Their First Job
articles.snippet: What employee manuals on health insurance, taxes and retirement plans should say, but don’t.
articles.abstract: What employee manuals on health insurance, taxes and retirement plans should say, but don’t.
articles.lead_paragraph: To the hundreds of thousands of young people who have landed entry-level jobs that come with health insurance and a retirement plan, I offer my congratulations. Things are tough out there right now, so you must be doing something right.

articles.headline: Lost in E-Mail, Tech Firms Face Self-Made Beast
articles.snippet: Some of the biggest technology companies have formed a group to fight information overload.
articles.abstract: Some of the biggest technology companies have formed a group to fight information overload.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  The onslaught of cellphone calls and e-mail and instant messages is fracturing attention spans and hurting productivity. It is a common complaint. But now the very companies that helped create the flood are trying to mop it up.

articles.headline: In France, Plans to Make a Bit More of the Bubbly
articles.snippet: With global demand for sparkling wine soaring, the French authorities are opening what could be the largest wave of expansion of Champagne vineyards in nearly a century.
articles.abstract: With global demand for sparkling wine soaring, the French authorities are opening what could be the largest wave of expansion of Champagne vineyards in nearly a century.
articles.lead_paragraph: MAGNEUX, France  Jean-Michel Petit, a third-generation beet farmer in this village, yearns to trade his earthy roots for the sparkle of Champagne.

articles.headline: The Search for a Missing Trader Goes Global
articles.snippet: Seemingly conflicting clues reflect the bizarre trajectory of the life of Samuel Israel III, the perpetrator of one of Wall Street’s biggest recent scams, who federal authorities believe is now on the run.
articles.abstract: Seemingly conflicting clues reflect the bizarre trajectory of the life of Samuel Israel III, the perpetrator of one of Wall Street’s biggest recent scams, who federal authorities believe is now on the run.
articles.lead_paragraph: Is Samuel Israel III dead or alive?
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Abha Bhattarai

articles.headline: Tim Russert, 58, NBC’s Face of Politics, Dies
articles.snippet: Mr. Russert, moderator of “Meet the Press,” was a fixture on television on Sunday mornings and election nights.
articles.abstract: Mr. Russert, moderator of “Meet the Press,” was a fixture on television on Sunday mornings and election nights.
articles.lead_paragraph: Tim Russert, a fixture in American homes on Sunday mornings and election nights since becoming moderator of “Meet the Press” nearly 17 years ago, died Friday after collapsing at the Washington bureau of NBC News. He was 58 and lived in Northwest Washington.

articles.headline: Oh Jerry, It’s No Longer Your Baby
articles.snippet: Since Yahoo went public in 1996, the company has had new owners — its shareholders — but it is unclear whether Jerry Yang, the company’s co-founder and chief executive, knows this.
articles.abstract: Since Yahoo went public in 1996, the company has had new owners — its shareholders — but it is unclear whether Jerry Yang, the company’s co-founder and chief executive, knows this.
articles.lead_paragraph: To: Jerry Yang

articles.headline: Some Cling to Hope for a Deal After Microsoft Discloses Details
articles.snippet: Microsoft disclosed the terms of its last offer to Yahoo, possible evidence that the company had not given up and might be campaigning to get the support of Yahoo shareholders.
articles.abstract: Microsoft disclosed the terms of its last offer to Yahoo, possible evidence that the company had not given up and might be campaigning to get the support of Yahoo shareholders.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  A day after Yahoo said it had ended talks with Microsoft and signed an advertising deal with Google, some of its shareholders were still holding on to hopes that some kind of marriage between Yahoo and Microsoft could be consummated.

articles.headline: Ireland Derails a Bid to Recast Europe’s Rules
articles.snippet: The defeat of a treaty to consolidate the European Union’s power shows that many Europeans feel alienated from it.
articles.abstract: The defeat of a treaty to consolidate the European Union’s power shows that many Europeans feel alienated from it.
articles.lead_paragraph: Europe was thrown into political turmoil on Friday by Ireland’s rejection of the Lisbon Treaty, a painstakingly negotiated blueprint for consolidating the European Union’s power and streamlining its increasingly unwieldy bureaucracy.
articles.byline: By Sarah Lyall and Stephen Castle

articles.headline: In Midwest, Rising Waters and Fears of Worse
articles.snippet: Continued flooding has raised the prospect of a year like 1993, when there was widespread misery and an economic cost of $20 billion.
articles.abstract: Continued flooding has raised the prospect of a year like 1993, when there was widespread misery and an economic cost of $20 billion.
articles.lead_paragraph: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa  All around the Midwest, the water just kept rising.
articles.byline: By Susan Saulny and Monica Davey

articles.headline: Plan Would Lift Saudi Oil Output
articles.snippet: Saudi Arabia’s plan to boost production next month was seen as a sign that the Saudis are nervous about the political and economic effect of high oil prices.
articles.abstract: Saudi Arabia’s plan to boost production next month was seen as a sign that the Saudis are nervous about the political and economic effect of high oil prices.
articles.lead_paragraph: Saudi Arabia, the world’s biggest oil exporter, is planning to increase its output next month by about a half-million barrels a day, according to analysts and oil traders who have been briefed by Saudi officials.

articles.headline: A Year Reshapes Hamas and Gaza
articles.snippet: Hamas has spread its authority across all aspects of life, and Gazans have not, as Israel and the United States hoped, risen up.
articles.abstract: Hamas has spread its authority across all aspects of life, and Gazans have not, as Israel and the United States hoped, risen up.
articles.lead_paragraph: GAZA  Cursing God in public here  a fairly common event in this benighted and besieged strip of Palestinian land  can now lead to prison. So can kissing in public. A judge ruled last week that a bank could not collect its contracted interest on a 10-year-old loan because Islam forbids charging interest.

articles.headline: Free and Flush, Russians Eager to Roam Abroad
articles.snippet: A people who under Communism were rarely allowed to travel abroad are now seeing the world. And relishing it.
articles.abstract: A people who under Communism were rarely allowed to travel abroad are now seeing the world. And relishing it.
articles.lead_paragraph: ANTALYA, Turkey  Yelena Kasyanova booked her trip at a local travel agency in about as much time it takes to drop by the market for a few groceries. She was soon lounging here by the Mediterranean, a working-class anybody from an anyplace deep in Russia, a child of the Soviet era who still remembers the humiliating strictures that once made it difficult to obtain a passport, let alone a plane ticket.

articles.headline: Approve This Deal, or Else
articles.snippet: A private equity firm that contributed funds to Washington Mutual as part of a capital infusion deal got a sweet package from the bank in return.
articles.abstract: A private equity firm that contributed funds to Washington Mutual as part of a capital infusion deal got a sweet package from the bank in return.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOWING to shareholder pressure, directors at Washington Mutual, the nation’s largest savings and loan, stripped Kerry K. Killinger, chairman and chief executive of the company, of his chairmanship on June 2. The board said it would appoint an independent chairman by July 1, and it instituted a majority voting standard for future director elections.

articles.headline: Indian to the Core, and an Oligarch
articles.snippet: India’s richest man, Mukesh Ambani, is shaping his country via capitalism, with echoes of Mohandas Gandhi.
articles.abstract: India’s richest man, Mukesh Ambani, is shaping his country via capitalism, with echoes of Mohandas Gandhi.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mumbai

articles.headline: Nuclear Ring Reportedly Had Advanced Design
articles.snippet: Investigators say they have found blueprints for an advanced nuclear weapon on computers belonging to a Pakistani nuclear scientist’s smuggling network.
articles.abstract: Investigators say they have found blueprints for an advanced nuclear weapon on computers belonging to a Pakistani nuclear scientist’s smuggling network.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  American and international investigators say that they have found the electronic blueprints for an advanced nuclear weapon on computers that belonged to the nuclear smuggling network run by Abdul Qadeer Khan, the rogue Pakistani nuclear scientist, but that they have not been able to determine whether they were sold to Iran or the smuggling ring’s other customers.

articles.headline: In ’74 Thesis, the Seeds of McCain’s War Views
articles.snippet: In an unpublished essay for the National War College, John McCain blamed domestic politics for weakening the will of American prisoners of war.
articles.abstract: In an unpublished essay for the National War College, John McCain blamed domestic politics for weakening the will of American prisoners of war.
articles.lead_paragraph: About a year after his release from a North Vietnamese prison camp, Cmdr. John S. McCain III sat down to address one of the most vexing questions confronting his fellow prisoners: Why did some choose to collaborate with the North Vietnamese?

articles.headline: Gay Couples Find Marriage Is a Mixed Bag
articles.snippet: In four years of gay marriage in Massachusetts, there has been bliss, painful divorce and everything in between.
articles.abstract: In four years of gay marriage in Massachusetts, there has been bliss, painful divorce and everything in between.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOSTON  Four years after Massachusetts became the first state to allow gay couples to marry, there have been blissful unions, painful divorces and everything in between.

articles.headline: Nearly Half of Wall St. Bank Profits Are Gone
articles.snippet: Since last July, seven of the nation’s largest financial companies lost almost half of the combined profits they had made between early 2004 and mid-2007.
articles.abstract: Since last July, seven of the nation’s largest financial companies lost almost half of the combined profits they had made between early 2004 and mid-2007.
articles.lead_paragraph: Only a year ago, Wall Street reveled in an era of superlatives: record deals, record profit, record pay. But a mere 12 months later, nearly half of the profits that major banks reaped during that age of riches have vanished.

articles.headline: Officials Fear Bomb Design Went to Others
articles.snippet: Four years after Abdul Qadeer Khan’s atomic black market operation was declared over, inspectors are wondering who may have received the blueprints for a nuclear weapon found on his computer network.
articles.abstract: Four years after Abdul Qadeer Khan’s atomic black market operation was declared over, inspectors are wondering who may have received the blueprints for a nuclear weapon found on his computer network.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Four years after Abdul Qadeer Khan, the leader of the world’s largest black market in nuclear technology, was put under house arrest and his operation declared shattered, international inspectors and Western officials are confronting a new mystery, this time over who may have received blueprints for a sophisticated and compact nuclear weapon found on his network’s computers.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and William J. Broad

articles.headline: A Delegator, Obama Picks When to Take Reins
articles.snippet: Senator Barack Obama is more inclined to focus on the big picture over the day-to-day whirl while managing his campaign.
articles.abstract: Senator Barack Obama is more inclined to focus on the big picture over the day-to-day whirl while managing his campaign.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  In the months leading up to Senator Barack Obama’s big loss in the Pennsylvania primary, he was a detached manager: around, but not meddling. Rarely on early-morning conference calls with his senior advisers, he delegated most decisions to others and did not immerse himself in all of the nuts and bolts of running for president.
articles.byline: By Jeff Zeleny and Jim Rutenberg

articles.headline: EMI’s New Boss Sees Cracks in Music World
articles.snippet: The takeover of the music company EMI, a cherished icon in Britain, by the private equity financier Guy Hands has been a chaotic culture clash.
articles.abstract: The takeover of the music company EMI, a cherished icon in Britain, by the private equity financier Guy Hands has been a chaotic culture clash.
articles.lead_paragraph: One evening last autumn a group of about 10 artist managers, including representatives for the pop stars Kylie Minogue and Robbie Williams as well as an executive who oversees the Beatles catalog, clustered around a table in an executive dining room at the London headquarters of EMI. The purpose was to size up the new boss, Guy Hands, and discuss the future of the record business.

articles.headline: With Tim Russert’s Death, NBC News Must Replace a Man of Many Roles
articles.snippet: While open speculation about who might replace Tim Russert in his various roles at NBC News has been muted, a list of insiders for his role on “Meet the Press” is already circulating.
articles.abstract: While open speculation about who might replace Tim Russert in his various roles at NBC News has been muted, a list of insiders for his role on “Meet the Press” is already circulating.
articles.lead_paragraph: The sudden death of Tim Russert has left the management of NBC News, for the moment at least, at a loss to contemplate how to replace him.
articles.byline: By Bill Carter and Jacques Steinberg

articles.headline: In Midwest Floods, a Broad Threat to Crops
articles.snippet: For farmers who have seen their fields turn to floodplains, the rain and flooding could not have come at a worse time.
articles.abstract: For farmers who have seen their fields turn to floodplains, the rain and flooding could not have come at a worse time.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEWHALL, Iowa  Here, in some of the best soil in the world, the stunted stalks of Dave Timmerman’s newly planted corn are wilting in what sometimes look more like rice paddies than the plains, the sunshine glinting off of pools of collected water. Although time is running out, he has yet to plant all of his soybean crop because the waterlogged soil cannot support his footsteps, much less heavy machinery.

articles.headline: In Mourning for a Man, and His Era
articles.snippet: Amid all the laurels and praise for the life of Tim Russert, journalists and politicians seem to be fearing that he may have taken a way of life with him.
articles.abstract: Amid all the laurels and praise for the life of Tim Russert, journalists and politicians seem to be fearing that he may have taken a way of life with him.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sunday was Father’s Day, but when I called my father to wish him a happy one, he was bereft. He had just finished watching the special edition of “Meet the Press” that was broadcast to honor its host, Tim Russert, who died Friday.
